description: Sutter Gutter baby. An SF institution. Great bartenders and classic vibes. If you can't make friends here, you probably don't belong in a dive bar.
author: Ryan C.

description:
WORST BAR IN FIDI! 
The owner is a huge (don't even want to use the derogatory word she deserves but ... female dog). I was charged for a drink I didn't order. When I confronted the bartender as I'm closing my tab out, the owner says I'm wrong and I or my friends ordered the drink. I assured her it must have been a mistake and she preceded to call the bartender that served me to prove that I did order the drink ... having a back and forth argument over 10$...what kind of bar owner does that? Even after she finally decided to give me my money back - FOR THE DRINK I DIDNT ORDER OR DRINK - she kept trying to prove a point that I or a friend ordered the drink and her bartenders never make mistakes. 
Such a horrible experience... DO NOT GO HERE. Sad part is my office just moved across the street and we're looking for a divey cheap bar in the area for happy hours. DEFINITELY, won't be this spot.
author: Alina B.

description:
Met up a girlfriend for a quick happy hour. We decided to go to Sutter Station on Wednesday, September 12th around 6pm. It was pretty crowded when we arrived, but after waiting around for a little bit, we managed to find two seats at the bar.

*Pear vodka w/soda ($5) x2
*Jameson irish whiskey ($5) x2
*Bud light ($4) x2

They have happy hour daily 12pm - 1pm and 5pm - 7pm. I don't really know what specials fall under this, but maybe the $5 jameson shots are a part of it? Not sure how much the bud light was, but I know each round was $14, so I'm guessing the price listed above. We were here for about two hours, so we had two rounds.

The atmosphere after work is very lively. A lot of people talking and drinking. The vibe is divey as it's dark and kinda old inside. The bartender was nice and gave us our rounds when we ordered them. Not sure if they serve food here, but I saw people bringing in food from other places. Good that's an option in case you get hungry.

Convenient if you want a few cheap drinks after work as the bus stop is right outside.
author: Elena N.

description:
It's divey but the experience is worth it. Have no mistake, Sutter Station Tavern is a no-nonsense watering hole for those seeking a drink at almost all hours of the day. 

The characters are colorful. The drinks are plenty (and reasonable). The service is affably gruff if you can imagine that. Perhaps therein lies the charm of Sutter Station. A dive bar in the middle of a quickly gentrifying city. Weekdays you have a post-work FiDi crowd and weekends they're fending crazies from stumbling in. All part and parcel of being a stalwart on Market Street. 

Daily drink specials and happy hours too.
author: Jon L.

description: Honestly, the place is really cool inside and has so much potential but the drinks were terrible. I didnt even drink all of mine and the bartender was kind of abrasive and not very nice. There are much better dive bars in the area.
author: Jessica G.

description: It was good, but Sutter was better. There are still great bartenders, but they recently let a veteran pair of bartenders go who were the main reason why I was a regular there. Now, I don't see much reason to go there since they were the atmosphere of the bar. They brought the dialogue, hilarity, and emotion of the bar. Now that it's gone, it's just a bar. There are still a couple there that do that, but I have to make sure they are there otherwise I don't see a reason to go at all. SAD!
author: Stephen M.

description:
Was attacked by an employee with a trash can... I tried to use the restroom and offered to buy a drink to do so. The bouncer- heavier set man in an orange tee shirt told the bartender to 'cut us off'- as in remove us from the bar when we were offering to purchase something to use the bathroom.

Things progressed from there. Once we left due to the bouncer's aggressive behavior toward us, he came out multiple times while we were waiting for our uber outside and physically threatened us.

At one point, he threw a huge recycling bin towards us at which time we called the police, who waited until we got a cab from this bar. I had to tell him verbally multiple times to move away from us because the police was on the phone as he made aggressive gestures. This is the photo of what was thrown at us (blue bin). Please do not go here. Unsafe for women alone at the least.
author: M. Kiera W.

description:
I cannot believe I have never been here.

Came early after work on a Wed. The martini glasses are frosted. This place has a nice "old man bar" feel that I enjoy. Hope it stays in SF forever and the the hipsters don't ruin it (Jeez I am getting old and sound like a little old lady!)
author: Amy W.

description: I love this place. It's right next to Bart station so it's nice to get a strong cheap drink before heading home. I like the owner Barbra she always has free snacks for us. I've never had any issues with the staff or using the bathroom and I've been going there for years. So I'm surprised from some of the other reviews.
author: Angela A.

description:
Sutter Station is one of the coolest "dive" bars in this city! I can't believe I haven't been here before, even though I've passed by it pretty often (without giving it a second glance. Womp!). 

I met a coworker here after work one early evening to hang for a bit. I arrived around 5:15 and seating was pretty easy but filled up quickly. The energy in this bar is awesome. The music is great and the bartenders are friendly (enough)-which is all you need. Also, people watching people watching is highly entertaining, haha!

Space is limited, grunge is high, and prices are far from dive-y. But hey, you're in FiDi, so not surprised. Also, there are pool tables and tv's if that's your jam.

Pro Tip: They now take credit cards (since they didn't ask me for cash I don't usually carry).
author: Shereen A.

description: This is my favorite bar in San Francisco. It's lovely and peaceful and the staff is friendly and professional. I ordered a tropical hurricane and the bartender and myself had no idea what went in it but she did her best and it was amazing and delicious! I will definitely be going back!
author: Julie H.

description: Awesome staff!! Great drink selection and chill atmosphere! Would definitely come back here! Our bartender even suggested more awesome places to check out
author: Dorian A.

description: Sutter is one of the best places in the city for a chill drink with your friends or coworkers. Bartenders are awesome and attentive. The city needs more Sutter Stations. Vote early and often for Sutter Station.
author: Mike P.

description:
Amazing place to stop in anytime. During parades and pride it is an oasis away from the hustle of market street. Love Barbara at the bar. She's my favorite. 

Jonathan Ader
Your Bay Area Real Estate Expert. 
~JonathanDreamHomes.com
author: Jonathan A.

description: This bar id's in a great location. They pour good drinks and it is priced very reasonably. The service was okay but the bartender did not have much of a personality unless you were a local, which i was not.
author: Tony T.

description:
Love me some Sutter Station! A great spot to grab drinks after work, especially when my homie Dwight is working (Monday and Wednesday evening, ladies.) Dude makes a mean cocktail and is vey pleasant company. 

I hadn't been to Sutter for a minute but my man was downtown and so we popped in for a start-of-the-evening cap and some advice on where to eat. Not only was my cocktail delightful and boyfran's beer fresh and cold, we also got a couple tips on where to wet our whistles next and dine on some delicious pizza. 

In a nutshell, Sutter is the spot for after work happy hours. I can't imagine someone not being able to find at least one thing they like about it. TVs, a juke box, two pool tables, popcorn, pizza on Fridays, plenty of seating, the list goes on. Try it and I'm sure you'll leave a happy, if not tipsy, camper!
author: Crystal C.

description: Horrible service. Bartender ignored me for 15 minutes before I decided to leave. I don't want to be the "crying minority", but if you serve 5 white people who came in after the patient Asian guy waiting at the bar, you leave little to assume. I mean seriously, you looked at me, looked away and walked over the guy that just walked in.
author: Andy W.

description: Visiting SF for the weekend. Wanted to find a place to watch the game and get a beer. Stumbled on this place. Super friendly, complimentary snacks, yum! Highly recommend stopping in.
author: Debbie C.

description: Love this neighborhood feeling bar!  Barbara the owner/bartender is amazing! Try her special drink the BA - delicious!
author: Susie O.

description: I go inside to try to shake off the workday at 4:15 since I got off early. The bouncer was cool, in an island Samoan kind of way, and he told me kindly where to find the restroom key after I downed my whiskey shot  and dipped some of my beer.as I went to locate said key it wasn't in place and so I went back to ask if it's gone it means someone is in there. He said yes. So I went back and waited. Enjoying the great dive bar feel. Then a kid comes out of the bathroom. An employee. A bar back type with Latino/white dark haired accents, that must have graduated to tender at some point.  He had the keys so I kindly ask him for them and he kindly said yes then handed them to me before he actually thought and said "whoa wait, are you a customer?" To which I replied, "yeah, do I need to buy a second drink from you to hit the head, or what" and that's when the female bartender vouched for me and he lost his cool and told me off, saying not to give him attitude, to which I replied "what?". So I went to the bathroom. I came out put the keys back and went back to my chair where my beer and shot were and  he eventually came over and said "I didn't mean to offend you but you just grabbed the keys out of my hand" and I replied "No, bullshit, I politely asked for them, and you handed them to me" and he came unglued and flipped out and told me off how I was aggro and I said "no dude. I'm cool... you, though, should go do more coke in the bathroom. It obviously calms you down" then I finished my drink and left never to come back. Thanks young brunette half Latin or Italian looking kid. I appreciate it. If you do more coke in the bathroom you should probably calm down first and shouldn't come out all scatterbrained and retroactively aggressive for no reason to paying customers who you insult with your unintelligence and unawareness. Everyone else in your bar was amazing but you. Owner take note.
author: Rick B.

description:
The "Cheer's" of S.F. Where everybody knows your name!! This was my hangout for years!! Barbara, Margaret, Fran, Ferdie, Meg, Robin, Randy, Tim, T.J., Rebecca ,Vepol, Dave, Carol, both Ken's, Brandi, Lil Joanne(RIP), Alex, T.L., Ross, Whitney, Farrell, Bryan, Sabian, Mark, Chopper, Diane, Brad, Lisa, Tim (shorts), Cat, Jeremy, John, Raji, Cheech, Angie, Joe(RIP), Andrea, Irish, Celine/C, Tara, Keto, Richard, Nick, Rahsaan, Kelly, Lingerie Lisa, Twan and the list goes on...
I wouldn't want to even begin to think of the money I spent here.
Great juke box!
Good prices!
No snobs!
Friendly!
Awesome Regulars!
Liar's Dice!
author: Sanddab Z.

description: Interesting location, not so interesting clientele, even less interesting bar tenders. No reason to visit if you're not a regular (aka meat head).
author: L Z.

description: Cleanest bar I have ever seen. Great spot to grab a drink and hang out. Bartender with beard and tattoos sure knows how to make a good drink!
author: Jackson S.

description: Best dive bar in the financial district (only dive bar in the financial district)?  I've introduced a lot of people to this place.  If you don't know it's there, it's easy to walk by .  I love starting the evening out here.  There is a pool table in the back.  Reasonable prices and lots of tables.
author: Greta R.

description: I work in the fidi and love this place. Know what you want and don't be picky, it's a dive bar not the Four Seasons. All are cool people who work there. I do miss Tara though!
author: Brad G.

description: Ah the good old "Sutter Gutter." In a land of $7 lattes and $6 toast, it's refreshing to still have an authentic dive bar Downtown. A comfortable an non-judgmental place to have a stiff drink or 3 before Noon on a Wednesday if that's your thing.
author: Andrew A.

description:
Don't want to wait 10 minutes for your cocktail to be made, as your "mixologist" slaps the ever living crap out of that poor basil leaf, and then pay $15 for it?

Come to Sutter Station. You know you love and miss a good dive.

Cash only, beer in a plastic cup, stiff pours, workers who get drunk and rowdy with you, pool tables, loud singing.

Of course, dives are the best when they're not packed to the brim, which Sutter Station can be during certain times of the day and certain events of the year.

Take it for what it is and have fun!
author: Lanie L.

description: It's a dive bar,customer service is horrid though the owner yells & curses at everyone, including me for having outside food, the beers arent that cold, they are garnished tho if need be, don't come here it's expensive and shitty.
author: Mar L.

description:
It was very rude from the boss bartender talked to us. 
Making fun of us because one of us had a hoodie, "he looked like a child, for sure he can not drink"
author: Rachid R.

description:
It's probably no surprise that the character I most relate to on "Cheers" is Norm...

Ed -- "Afternoon, everybody!"
Customers -- "ED!"
Woody -- "Hey, Mr. U, what do you say to a cold one?"
Ed -- "See you later, boss. I'll be at the Sutter Gutter."

When I meet people in the middle of a work day, my usual choice is Starbucks or Peet's. Coffee is the ideal noncommittal beverage for a noncommittal conversation. But I have one friend and former colleague I see every now and then in the FiDi, and when I first suggested meeting up for coffee, we ended up here. At first, I was a bit taken aback not because I'm some prude but I kept having images of a made-for-TV movie made back in the 70's when some married alcoholic ad agency guy would stumble out of a bar too scared to face his judgmental wife at home. Y'see, he got fired for being drunk at a big client presentation that lost his agency its big account. Sutter Station looks just like one of those lonelyhearts bars. What can I say? I like the place.

If Current TV ever decided to remake "Cheers" in San Francisco, this is the tavern they should use because the bartenders are friendly and the taps are full (see photo). They have Guinness right out of the tap, which was nice since I just came back from Dublin where I took the tour of the storehouse and got the free pint. We were having a great time. So the funniest thing happened the last time I was there. I was approached by a fellow Yelper who recognized me from my profile, and he was gushing about how great he thought my reviews were. My friend was watching this gobsmacked by the outpouring of affection to me. He actually said it was like meeting a celebrity. I must have turned fifty shades of red. No autographs please.

DRINKS - 4 stars...good for a midday pick-me-up 
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...Cheers, SF-style 
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...pours 'em just fine 
TOTAL - 4 stars...You want to go where people know, people are all the same... you want to go where everybody knows your name... ED!
author: Ed U.

description: Cute dive bar. But the prices are not dive-ish at all. $9 for a simple Rum & Coke, $13 for a Bulleit Old Fashion. $22 + tip. I would have saved $ at the much nicer House of Shields across the street... or enjoyed a nicer drink at the uber posh Pied Piper @ the Sheraton Palace. I don't get it. First time is the last time.
author: David A.

description:
Dwight is awesome. Manager...not so much. 


I'm only continuing to type because I have to..
author: Christine G.

description:
1 star for opening at 6am. 1 star for being located steps from the Montgomery BART Station. And 1 more star for having a Wells Fargo ATM steps from their entrance. What exactly is Sutter Station? It's a dark bar that could be considered a dive if it wasn't for its prices. $6 for a Stella pint isn't my idea of a deal. However they do have $3 Buds all day, everyday and I do believe they have a happy hour of some sorts on the weekdays except Friday's. Prices are high, service is decent, and they have a clean bathroom, a pool table and plenty of televisions. You can't ask for much more from a San Francisco watering hole that opens at 6am.

Pros:
+ Steps away from BART
+ Wells Fargo ATM 2 doors down
+ $3 Buds
+ Televisions and clean bathrooms
+ Friendly bartenders
+ Opens at 6am

Cons:
- Pricey 
- Cash only
author: Alexander E.

description: I am 52 years old and have been in the military 30 years. I was denied access to this establishment because the "doorman"  would not accept a military ID and insisted on a Drivers License. He also was a total D bag about it. Him and this establishment showed Zero respect. Contrary, We went next door, to Per Diem, flashed my ID and walked right in and had a great time. Way to treat your customers Mr highly qualified to do nothing but check ID's Doorman.
author: Bill C.

description:
Any bar that is situated on lower market is de facto a "dive" bar. Sutter Station fits this bill to a T. They have cheap drinks and a colorful array of patrons. 

Normally I would not go here but heck it was Saint Pats and some buddies egged me into going. 

If you want a cheap buzz this is your kinda place.
author: David G.

description:
While I appreciate a "dive bar" being located relatively close to my work, the crowds and service are not worth putting up with. This place gets packed after work and you have to squeeze through lots of people. Then at the bar, you're lucky if you can get served within a few minutes.

Better off either paying a little more elsewhere or just going back to your hood and drinking close to home.
author: Jon T.

description:
Some friends and I were out for lunch and one suggested getting drinks. It was only about 3pm but we were down. It was 5 o'clock somewhere, right?

Sutter Station is not far off from the Montgomery muni/bart stop. Quite easy to find. 

Service is nice and friendly. I ordered a Black&Tan while everyone else got a midori sour, pint of Guinness, and a pint of some sort of beer that I can't remember the name of.

Anyway, everything was pretty cheap. Environment was light hearted and chill. The people who seem to go here the most are business folks looking for a small break with some coworkers or just older people catching up. I felt like we were the youngest group in there.

Cool spot.
author: Sofia R.

description:
Sutter Station is a super wallet-friendly bar on Market St. in the financial district. Sure, it's a little grimy, but you can get a bottle of Bud for $3 here. Nine dollars later, the concept of cleanliness becomes a little blurry anyway.

Aside from providing a cheap buzz, Sutter Station is also not a bad place to catch a game. Their TV sets ain't super HD or whatever, but is High Definition really high definition anymore after several drinks? 

A great place to dodge the Bougie that you may encounter at Novela/Local Edition. No neckties or 3 inch pumps small-talking you here. Just a lively crowd with a slight hint of rachet. Remember to bring CASH!
author: Ringo M.

description:
Tried to use restroom to wash my hands, the bartender would not let me because I was not a customer. 
Now I never will be a customer, that's horrible customer service
author: Mike O.

description: Nice big bar with plenty of room and comfy seating areas. Drinks were well priced and atmosphere was good. Seemed like a place you'd go hang with friends for a good amount of time instead of an hour long stop on a bar crawl, it that makes sense to people. Pizza Fridays are a good time too.
author: Ryan J.

description: Oh Sutter Station, you are a gem. The drinks are strong, the fidi suits are afraid of this place, and the bartenders are friendly (thanks for the brownie!). This  is my kind of place. The staff is on point too- one errant popcorn kernel on our table was quickly swiped away-  they don't mess around. OK so my ONE gripe- cash only- wah wah. Luckily it's pretty centrally located so there are ATMS everywhere (and they have one on site).
author: Alyssa J.

description:
Women, run like hell if you see the bouncer who was working on 9/21/16 around 5pm (I don't have his name yet but I'll get it, and I will also be posting his picture). He threw me out because I tried to go to the bathroom before buying a drink. (As if it's safe to leave a drink alone anywhere, much less a dive.) He didn't ask if I was staying; he was on my case.

There were only a couple of women in there, and it's pretty obvious why. Sutter Station employs lowlifes.
author: Carrie S.

description:
Stopped by here for a drink while in the area.  Grimey but cheap.  Bathroom was better than expected, but from judging by the bar, I had really low expectations to begin with!

The booze was plentiful, and the bartender poured the drinks strong.  Given the location, you'd expect more, but for the price, it's happily less.  It's cheap, easy, and quick!  Well played, Sutter.  Well played.
author: Jes G.

description:
Nice bar for what it is. It's listed as a dive bar but, I wouldn't classify it as such. It was full when I was there but, it is a large bar and there was room to move around so that you don't feel like a sardine. 

Imo, the drinks were a tad bit expensive for what I'm use to but, I guess that's expected being that I was in San Francisco. The bartender Dwight was very sweet and handsome ... his sister (Tiana) was also personable & a nice young lady. Only downfall is that it's cash only (come on now!).  Overall I had a good experience there.
author: J E.

description: This is one of the worst bars I've ever been to. The staff is not friendly, it reeks of smoke inside, the drinks are overpriced, and the bathroom is a mess. Highly recommend avoiding.
author: Kevin H.

description: Definitely a dive bar. Easily accessible, prices were affordable. Staff super friendly and accommodating. One of the workers had a small snake around his snake which was pretty cool. Drinks were strong but good and there was a pretty cool and unique crowd there. Would definitely go there again, looked pretty clean as well.
author: Christine V.

description:
This place is ridiculous. I came here for happy hour the other night, and I was stoked to find out that I wouldn't be dropping $100 some odd dollars for a night of drinking.

A couple of old fashioned at this place are only $10! Granted, it is just house whiskey, so it isn't exactly the highest quality. But it was a decent drink for the same price as a beer most places. Now, I love beer, don't get me wrong, but I LOVE whiskey.

The ambience is great, as well. It was crowded, but not unreasonably loud. And this was during the football game! Definitely a comfortable place to catch up with an old friend.

The last drink we ordered, a couple of martinis, were almost entirely gin. Which normally I wouldn't complain about. And probably would have loved, if it had been my first drink. But at the end of the night, it was a little much.

They also have a couple of pool tables in the back. I am not sure how much it costs to play, but it is cool to know you have the option if you would like. If it had not been for the allure of nearby ramen and the football game, I probably would have played.

Anyway, fun cheap place to pick up a few after-work drinks. I am sure I will be back at some point.
author: Kevin B.

description: My new favorite bar in San Francisco. Friendly staff and regulars. Great door man super nice. My husband and I had a blast playing pool. Love the owner & good prices.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Chill dive bar in the City in the middle of the FiDi. 

After having lunch with our friends in the FiDi, Jeff asked where he can get a cocktail and they suggested Sutter Station as our go to. I remembered this place when I used to work off Bush & Montgomery and I'd come with my former coworkers for a bloody mary for those late mornings or Hair of a Dog cocktails for those Monday hungovers LOL or happy hour. I couldn't believe this place is still open after all of these years! 

We chilled here for an hour before our bart ride back to SFO. I had a Hendricks gin and tonic cocktails and my honey was happy with his jameson highballs. 
Played pool to pass the time!
author: Mika D.

description: Super cool afternoon joint to hangout and have a beer or two. My man and I had a great time here playing pool and they are seriously the most cozy and friendliest bar atmospheres I've ever experienced. With the complimentary snacks (and free pizza on Fridays!) this bar has instantly become one of my favorites. I loved playing all the roots reggae jams (and classics) on their juke box as well. Great location in the heart of the financial district. Can't wait to return!
author: K. J.

description:
Bad: overpriced beers and coffee. Coffee costs just as much as a beer and has no free refills. Doesn't take debit/credit cards forcing you to use the ATM. Saw roaches (the nasty infestation bug) while playing pool... And no music plays unless you put money in the juke box. Regarding the juke box, I paid for a whole album of "The Doors" and it didn't even work and just ate my money. 

Good: Great bartenders and a great place to come bring your food for lunch and just hang out.
author: Diana S.

description:
Time to get drinking after working in the Financial District area!  Quick service with the drinks coming out in a dandy!

Plus, complimentary pizza when you stay till 7ish and entered during happy hour at 5:30!  Yum!

Dolla dolla bill y'all!  ...For a bowl of popcorns!  

Good ole jukebox on the side, TV in the front and pool table in the back of this divey bar, makes it a complete package!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Great place! I really love most of the bartenders (the ones that look like they've been working here forever), happy hour gets you $3 whiskey, and on Fridays there's free food - everything from pizza to shrimp cocktails.

One drawback is that it gets packed after work, with people who all come from the same workplace and continue talking obnoxiously about work. Ugh. But whatever I don't come here to mingle, and they can't help who comes in, so 5 stars.
author: S. A. K.

description:
Call it the FiDilemma: it's 5pm and you need an adult beverage. You finally break free of your air conditioned sweatshop, pull out the Yelp app, and realize there are two kind of establishments at your behest. You recognize the first kind: an over-designed bar with $12 Craft Cocktails and dudes with tucked in shirts braying about funding and saying things like "great space." You lament with a shiver, "if only there was a dive bar nearby. Where real people drink!"

The counterpoint to this dilemma is practically Grecian in its irony. Sutter Station is like getting blasted with a flamethrower after complaining about the the cold. It's cash only, crowded, dingy, balmy, noisy, and charmless. There are real people sure, but they're mostly glued to the game, or wondering how the fuck you got in there. You might find a few folks playing at the pool table in the back.

Drinks are cheap. There's popcorn for a dollar. This is a coin flip kinda place.

Obligatory Simpsons Reference: "This isn't faux dive. This is a dive!"

Menu Readability: I didn't see one, nor did I look.

Need to mention: This place promises free Wi-Fi but you should never pull out your laptop there.

What this place teaches me about myself: I shouldn't complain, lest this spot become "upgraded" to a spiked kombucha tavern.
author: Vivek S.

description:
Looking to play a bit of pool near the convention center. Two tables, decent cues.  Bit cramped. 

Got to play a few guys from their APA team, supposedly the tables get pretty busy. Will be back.
author: Michael B.

description: Awful place - super aggressive staff on the doors and disinterested behind the bar. Cash only? Guys, it's 2015. You're only cash only because you think it's "divey" and "cool". Nonsense - you know what it is? Inconvenient, that's what.  Oh, and a tax dodge.  Credit card processing fees are like less than 2%. Cash only my ass.
author: David T.

description:
I've not been in this place in 20-25 years but last night a new gal I just met wanted to go there.  I had researched other places to meet but many were closed by the time we got together.

This is a big dive of a bar, dirty, noisy and I've not seen so many rough looking types in a long time, but then I don't spend as much time in the financial district as I have in past years and certainly not in places like this...  Lots of dudes in black leather jackets (why don't we see them on the nearby streets or have the nearby corporations gone  thug or do they beam them in or sneak in on BART?)

Frankly it was a disaster.  I could not hear anything she was saying as the ass/freak next to our table was loud enough to be heard in civic center and the overall noise level was 125 out of 100.  So if you are going there for anyting more than a crowded MUNI ride with a bunch of durnk street roudies I woud not bother.

The place was about as clean as a MUNI bus in service for two straight days so yes this is a dive bar if you love dirty noisy dive bars this is the place for you.  if you want to meet someone and chat forget it.

The gal and I did not connect because we made a bad choice for a place to meet... I think Elliott Ness will be raiding this place for some reason even after all of these years, it is probably on the California ABC's most wanted list.
author: Dalt W.

description:
Love to play pool here late at night. However, it's bullsh*t that they close at 1am. WTF!?!?! It says you close at 2am. 

There are plenty of people in the bar who want to drink and play pool.  Now I have to call it an early night?  

I just put about 8 dollars into the jukebox and they called "last call". 

I loved this place but now I don't think I'll ever return to this place. 

I'm super disappointed.  When I asked the staff why last call was at 1:15am, they told me the owner wants to leave by 2am. So I order a drink for last call and by 1:45 I am being told to hurry up by the staff. 

Come on!
author: Christopher R.

description:
You're a working professional and time is money.

You want to get soused without leaving the comforts of the FiDi.

You opt for reliable ol' "Sutter Gutter" because it has free Wi-Fi and sports and God knows how much you love sports.

Call your bros and do some shots with the bartenders because it's lunchtime and the bartenders are all about mid-day shots here.

Go back to work drunk and sell some mutual funds to people who don't realize you have no idea what you're doing.
author: Keane L.

description: Sutter Station is definitely a dive bar and looks to be filled with regulars and business people from FiDi getting off work. The bar area is pretty big and looks like they have a pretty good selection of alcohol. The bartenders seemed pretty cool. They only take cash, but they do have an ATM. Also, they have a couple of pool tables in a narrow area of the bar, which would probably annoy me if I were playing a game of pool since the ATM machine is in the same area as well as the back entrance. And my friend told me they only have one bathroom so they have that going on for them. I would only come here again if I was meeting up with some friends.
author: Vanessa S.

description: Door man was extremely rude and slightly sexist my friends and I will never go here again..........
author: Amanda S.

description:
At a glance, this place looks great.  Dark, classy looking dive bar with quality furnishing and a few TVs.  It's also conveniently located right above the Montgomery BART station.   The flaws, however, are many.  

First of all, the bathroom is a joke.  It's filthy, but that's not the problem. The problem is that you have to ask the bartender for a key every time you have to piss, and every time you ask, he'll act like you're becoming a burden.   It's almost like he don't like the clientele staying for more than one drink.  

The bartender I speak of is a clean-cut, dark haired guy in his 30s.  He's a real ass. I've been to the place twice, and within that limited time I've seen him refuse to serve an obvious tourist because the dude had an energy drink with him, and I've seen him scream at a young lady working with him for putting too much booze in a whiskey sour.  He'll also do his best to ignore you.  This guy doesn't want to be working at Sutter Station, and he doesn't want you drinking there.

The other serious problem with this place is that it doesn't keep a regular schedule.  Before my two visits here, I had, on numerous occasions, found the place closed.  They have 'hours' listed, but those mean nothing.  Even if you ignore my suggestion to avoid this spot, don't bother making it an actual planned destination.  Chances are you'll get there and it'll be closed.

Wish there were more affordable bars in the area, so this place would close, or, better yet, reopen with some new management.
author: Christopher F.

description:
I wish you could actually give a place 0 stars.

A couple weeks back, I had a plan to meet a half dozen or so former co-workers for a few drinks after work.  And the Sutter saloon was a good location in between our two work places.  As soon as I walk in wearing my backpack, the bartender says "YOU CAN'T COME IN HERE WITH THAT."  
"What my backpack?"
"NO, THE GATORADE BOTTLE ON THE SIDE OF THE BACKPACK."
"I can't bring a half filled Gatorade bottle into the bar?"
"NO"
"Why not?"
"BECAUSE."

Funny because no other bar in the city has such a stupid rule that they would actually enforce it without using their common sense.  

I just came from work.  What does he think?  I am smuggling in a mixed drink in my Gatorade bottle.  Or I am going to mix a Budweiser in my Gatorade bottle and walk out of the bar?

So by being a jerk and providing no logic to your rule - That's a good way to lose business.  It would've been at least a couple hundred bucks in their till (and perhaps more on subsequent trips to the bar) for a couple hours of drinking by 8 or so folks.  
But, they'll never get it now.
author: JimJim M.

description:
If you like weak drinks at prices you find at airport bars, with suburbanites and generic people who are silly and uncouth, have nothing to say, but giggle at people and talk about uneducated things ..well, then check this place out!

I was served by a hipster bartender yesterday with an attitude. He makes it clear who he LIKES, and who he does NOT like, no matter how much cash you put down.

He sneaked outside and wrote some bar specials on the sign outside, but conveniently didn't tell those of us already sitting on bar stools about those specials. So he continued to charge us full price.

When confronted about a $3 rum special, he replied, "that was a mistake, it's $5"

no thanks..I don't need the immaturity of attitude from a loser hipster who pours drinks for a living. I'll take my money somewhere which is REAL San Francisco, not an "airport bar" catering to boring suburbanites who don't realize they are getting ripped off by their overpriced drinks.
author: Matt B.

description: Come here if you want to be judged and treated like a child by the rotting witch of an owner. I come here quite often because I have friends that always want to play pool. I spent a decent amount at the bar and mind my own business just chatting with friend. The owner constantly stalks me asking for my id several times and says she knows I come here a lot and recognizes me but she insists on checking it again and taking it away from me. Also, my friend accompanied me into the bathroom because I have her hold my purse because I refuse to set it down anywhere because it is FILTHY. When we came out she YELLED at us saying YOU CANT GO IN THE BATHROOM TOGETHER! There is nice way to let your patrons know your rules about your disgusting bathroom than to yell at them like a child in front of everyone in the establishment. Yes, we look young but that is no way to treat a paying customer.
author: Char L.

description: The bar had horrible service. Would not allow bar customers to use restroom. Will never recommend service at this bar.
author: John S.

description: Place has the rudest bartender. Ugly ass bitch named Lisa. Rudest fucking person I've ever met. She needs to be fired. She cussed at us when she told us we need cash. Don't go here!
author: Brent w.

description:
One of the best bars I've been to in the city: And this happened to be on a trip meant for business than pleasure. 

Having to wait an hour and a half for my friend to get out of work to have lunch, I decided to kill my time at a bar with a brew. I walk on Market, and I fortunately found this place. 

This place is like a hole-in-the-wall bar, but it definitely had some character when I came in. It was a small and intimate bar, with pool tables and a jukebox in the back, and a few tables in the front. 

It was around noon, so the only people in were those either by themselves for lunch, or buddies forgoing eats for drinks. I of course being a part of the former crowd, decided to grab a beer, which was $4.50 (yech). That was a little irritating. 

Then, an extra waitress clocked in, Jessica :), which made things at the bar go so much more smoother. 

I noticed everyone around me having Bloody Mary's, so I thought, "F*** it, let's do it."

Jessica then made a STRONG Bloody Mary for me, which was good for bar standard. She asked me if I liked mine spicy, and of course with my Pakistani blood, I need spice or I'd rather die twice. 

Unfortunately after having a bit of fun, I realized 90 minutes had passed and I was late for lunch. That tells you something if you had fun at a bar by going yourself. The money was well spent :), I will definitely come back (on Thursdays at noon, when I can hahahaha!)
author: Atif K.

description: Divey and friendly. I finally walked in after work, on the  Sutter Street side. Happy Hour pricing still in effect at 8:30pm, $3 gin+tonic. I will be back, my kind of place.
author: Frank L.

description: They were showing the Niners game and they made one amazing Bloody Mary. Best I've had in SF so far.
author: Jeff S.

description: RACIST BAR DISCRIMINATING AGAINST ASIAN WOMEN. Please do not support this establishment, they are garbage people. Should you care to be served by discriminatory scum then you have found your place. Never in my life have I been so offended. Garbage+Racist+Scum=Sutter Station.
author: Bill M.

description: Zero stars. I went to this place last night with about 6 friends and the staff was disrespectful and rude to us. We are from out of town and some friends from the bay recommended this bar, but it ended up being disappointing. My friends from the bay area were surprised how horrible the staff was and will no longer go there as well.This bar was the one and only thing that I hated about my visit to San Francisco. This place is not fun, we left as soon as I finished my expensive drink. Not a dive bar. Do not go to this bar. Go to ANY other bar, no complaints about any other bars.
author: Czesa M.

description:
good drinks, cool security guy, and one of the cleanest and good-smelling bathrooms ive ever walked into at a dive bar. 

coming back for sure
author: Talia R.

description: Just a tip, If you are a tourist better bring your passport. Because they won't honor international drivers License. Dang!
author: Saileene Y.

description: I love going to this dive bar for a beer two.  Very friendly staff and reasonable prices.  They finally started accepting credit cards for a minimum of $25.  I am not sure if they realize that is actually against their contract with Visa and MasterCard.  Either way, I enjoy coming here.  When you are here, it doesn't feel like you are still in the financial district.
author: Jeremy S.

description: Owner was a real b**ch!! Rude and non appreciative of the customers. The old woman should just pack it in and leave it to a younger crowd. I cannot stress enough how I will never return to that bar. I watched her be rude to others and then to me. Zero stars.
author: Uni V.

description: Bad mojo. Would not let a 52 year old with a military id in because there birthday wasn't on is id. The birthday isn't on there for security reasons.
author: Karen S.

description:
Murkey glass barback mirrors reflect poorly lit murals of cablecars all bound for "Sutter Street Station". FiDi folk, flashing white teeth from within their Armani Suits drink Lagunitas IPA, White Wine or Martinis sit in scalloped leather booths with asymmetrical tables and slowly come alive to an old school jukebox blasting everything from JJ Cale to Mariachi to Justin Bieber. 

Map consulting tourists appear out of place, as the rest of the clientele wait for their BART or Muni train in an alcohol fueled haze from a strongly poured (and appropriately priced) drink, spreading warmth within as the world slowly opens from the constricting haze of the day into the freedom of a twilight unburdened by care and responsibility. 

An old-school bar, this. Non-descript, but perfect to soak in the intriguing milleu of downtown San Francisco before you move on to more entertaining places.
author: Casey U.

description:
I don't even know where to begin to describe why and how much I loved this place hahaha seriously!
on vacation my boyfriend & I dropped in to escape the heat and our tired feet for a beer, which turned into 2 which turned into us losing count of how many we drank.
So many friendly people from other travelers, local regulars to the bartenders. We played pool, we hogged the juke box lol (and were complimented on our song choices), we got to meet & hold the bar backs albino snake, we made a friend who walked us down to the Ferry Building, and probably more stuff I can't remember but this is a great place to feel at home right away I can see why they have so many regulars.
author: Kat Q.

description: Walked here from a giants game and subsequently had to use the restroom, immediately was bombarded by 2 employees who told us the owner said we had to buy a drink before we could use the restroom! They wouldnt give us the key and kept insisting until our friend bought a drink. This is terrible customer service and your biggest emphasis should be on that alone. Only gave 2 stars because the bartender was great. Otherwise the owner should probably look for another line of work. Forgot to add this bar is cash only. What is this the 19th century? Its 2015...
author: T J.

description:
I would give the actual venue 3 stars. The drink special, although well priced for downtown San Francisco @ a $3 beer, was pretty narrow-minded. You could get Bud but not Bud Light. They need to add a little more variety to that special.

The extra star comes from one of the bartenders there that was super friendly. He was exactly what the service profession is about. Helpful with our orders and a great, kind conversationalist. Very laid back.

The clientele was overall very nice. You get a lot of variety from the people coming in off the main street.
author: Peter H.

description: This is not a dive bar. $16 for a beer and regular crown. Staff was crazy rude, especially bartender. Carded my friends three separate times. You have to get the key from staff to use the bathroom??? Zero stools in pool table area. Staff would not let us take chairs over. Only reason it gets 2 stars is quantity of TVs, cleanliness and bug daddy IPA was fantastic. Would not ever come back.
author: Ruben L.

description: I don't really get why everyone is complaining. This place is a hole in the wall, and a great one. As for service, I was asked if I wanted another beer as soon as mine ran out, almost every time. The bartender, Savannah, was awesome, and even kicked out some dude who was kept touching me because he was so fucked up. It wasnt too crowded, there was a great mix of people, and it just smelled like a bar. Yelp has a lot of pussies who think that being able to smell beer over their appletini is a bad thing.
author: Daniel M.

description: Bartender was extremely rude to customers including myself. She's drinking behind the bar. Saw her grab an employee while he was ordering products for the bar. That's enough a for a lawsuit, sweetheart.
author: A. S.

description:
This is an after work spot extraordinaire! Sutter Station is long and narrow and crowded and sort of really fun. A pool table and drinks for the working man. If you want to blend in on the average person trip, you come here and get it while it's solid.
Watch some sports and drink some beer and talk to the regulars who surround you.

I've been here about six times in my life and every time it's all about just relaxing and not being in a situation.

Cheers!
author: Alexander R.

description: Sutter station is a total dive bar that has no pretenses about it.  It is different from the usual FiDi bar. I was there on a Friday evening and as expected, it was super loud and crowded. Cash only is a bit of a pain.
author: Sunil R.

description:
Saltiest Biggest Nuts in Town...and i'm not just talking about the peanuts.  Put in a couple dollars in the juke box, pull up a bar stool, settle in and sip on a Bud while getting your gab on with some regular patrons.

The bartenders are very friendly, the drinks are cheap, and its located right next to a bart stop  (montgomery).

I don't have any reason to come here often, except for that its right by the bus I take to head over to a friend's place in PacHeighs/Polk St.  

But  if you're in the area, pop in and get a beer.

(ps..the nuts are a 1.00 and they are really big, this isn't a joke.)
author: leahnora r.

description:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hAYSIgXj2ZY... I'm back, motherfucker.

Where have I been for the past year, you ask?  Let me give you a hint: I pay nearly ten dollars a day to commute less than thirty miles roundtrip on a decrepit public transportation system developed in the 70's that spends more money on installing new seat covers (the "lipstick on a pig" analogy has never proven more relevant) than it does retrofitting the track infrastructure to protect its customers from inevitable major earthquakes in one of the most seismically active regions of the US.  

That's right...where ELSE would I be, but San Francisco.

In short, I have found this place to be a veritable cesspool of vagrants, drug addicts, alcoholics, software developers posing as hipsters, militant communists, Eurotrash and the American equivalent: Marinatrash...    

...But for at least two hours each day during the week, Barbara makes it all go away.  
  
Godspeed, young lady.  And God bless Sutter Station. 

-The Taco Truck Nazi
author: Mike K.

description:
One of my favorite places in the city.

Sutter Station is my go-to dive bar for a post-work drink. Happy Hour is M-F from 7-9pm - only $3 for all well drinks! The staff is always extremely warm and friendly, from the doormen, to the bartenders, to the infamous owner Ms.Barbara. Barbara is a fierce little Italian (?) woman with a heart of gold and a no-bullshit attitude ... you have no choice but to adore her. I repeat, ADORE her.

Drinks are strong, service is fast, vibe is mellow, and the crowd is eclectic. Being that it's in the FiDi, you get plenty of business folks in suits and loosened-ties. Given it's dive-y nature, you also get the less glamorous, although fantastic, regulars.

As for tunes, the jukebox holds a sub-par repertoire. That being said, you can't really go wrong with anything Prince or Beatles. (And such is expected at a dive bar.)

The bar is located mere feet away from Montgomery St. BART/Muni and several bus stops. So whether you're heading back home to the East Bay like me, or off to another stop in the city, transportation options are abundant and convenient. 

If you're looking to get a little fancy before (or after), Local Edition right across the street is pretty impressive and a totally different feel. Just make sure you tighten that tie.

P.S. Free snacks and pizza on Fridays. It'll be packed, but it's worthwhile.
author: Anna H.

description:
CASH ONLY... um, this is hard for me because The Dr. calls me 'paperless' Well, I am but I loved the dark, rustic, divvy-ness. 

We had just left the madness of the Ferry Building on a Saturday afternoon and were getting grumpy from starvation when we decided an adult beverage would seriously improve our spirits. The Dr. had beer, I had vodka. He paid the reasonable tab and all was well in our world.
author: Julie H.

description:
I was strolling down Market the other day, en route to my office late at night after spending some QT with co-workers at the Old Ship Saloon in the Embarcadero/FiDi area of the city. I noticed all sorts of commotion coming out of this random bar around Second Street, so I had to check it out. Turns out, it was Sutter Station... and I've heard many a drunken tales from friends after visits to this joint... so I felt compelled to slug a $3 Budweiser and use the bathroom before hopping on the MUNI.

In just 10 minutes, I saw a rotund woman modeling lingerie (I guess it's a regular occurrence here?). A questionably homeless guy jamming his filthy paws into a popcorn machine, then getting kicked out of the bar. And a bouncer cleaning up a huge pile of vomit by the pool table in the back as if he were picking up dog poop (inside-out trash bag style). You'd think there'd be a better method, no?

So much action in so little time... I wonder what normally transpires in the period of a typical half-hour here?
author: Ruggy J.

description:
First great thing: it's a dive. Second great thing: drinks are pretty cheap. 

I met a few people here on a Friday around 6, and yes, sweet Jesus, it was CROWDED. We did manage to get a table, but that was only because one of our group got there before work let out. Like sardines. I have a bit of a crowd issue, and the boyfriend is over 6'6", so neither of us were particularly comfortable. Impossible to move, difficult to get to the bar for more drinks without throwing elbows. Emptied out a little after about eight; it's more of an after-work crowd than a nightlife crowd.

The bartenders are great, especially considering the volume during peak hours.

All in all, really crowded but fun-- I drank enough to fall off my shoes. How can you hate that? (My ankles hated that.)
author: Christine R.

description:
It's not pretty, but that's how I like my dive bars, and Sutter Station is one of the best. The drinks are stiff and people leave you alone so you can focus on the only reason you'd come into the bar: getting hammered. 

Few better places to forget about your problems for awhile.
author: Carlos D.

description:
I love this place because it's timeless. 

I wish their new busser guy (I've been coming here before he even started) -- I wish he wouldn't treat me like garbage, call me "a girl," and give me ten dollars back (not even the whole amount I paid during the whole evening that he ruined) all because I asked him not to scream behind my ear.
author: Pablo M.

description: If you like chill dive bars, you will like Sutter Station.  Cheap drinks, good pours, no nonsense, cash only.  My kinda place.  This is my local when I stay at the nearby Hyatt.
author: Chris A.

description: The bartenders and crowd were awesome. Except for one creepy dude which the bartender kicked out for us. It was really fun and holy shots of Fireball with which you can get a small beer for $1.
author: Erika L.

description: Sutter Station has been around forever, and is a great local bar in SF right at Market and Sansome. It is warm and friendly, and has pool table in the back. People are mostly locals but are pretty friendly. I do not know if they serve food there, but the drinks are plentiful and it looks a bit like Cheers! on TV as for as atmosphere. Give it a try.
author: Jeffrey K.

description: Cool atmosphere but the bartenders are really snooty, the service was poor, and you need a key to use the bathroom, that gets old QUICK!
author: Ashley B.

description:
I have an affinity for dive bars. Seedy little shacks with cold beer and stale air. This fits the bill.

They have pool tables in the rear. That's cool. There's usually a Latino dude hustling back there (custom cue and all), so you've been warned.
author: Wes T.

description: The bartender was super rude on a monday and I walked out end of story and my business.......
author: Pat C.

description:
I usually like dive bars, but every time I leave this place, I feel like I need a showwer. A long hot shower. There are some nasty people in the place. I don't know if they still have it, but in th 90s, they would get girls to wear lingerie and then raffle off the undies at the end of the night. Nasty. 

Was also involved in a sizable brawl involving about ten people in here about ten years ago where my friend ended up with a broken nose.
author: Jim B.

description:
Just another bar. 

This place is right across the street from where I work so my co-workers and I used to frequent this place quite a lot. There is really nothing special here. There are pool tables and a jukebox in the back with alright music. I only like the jukebox because it has Tupac's greatest hits album. The drinks are cheap but they only accept cash. It is a dive bar so the crowd consists of regulars but you do on occasions get the work crowd. A lot of bike messengers frequent the place as well. The staff is rather friendly on good days and the location is prime. The BART and Muni station is right in front. 

There is a TV in the center of the Bar which is great for catching the game. There is no dancing but if the crowd gets rowdy enough then they'll throw it down. This is a good place to go to get cheap drinks then go to another spot around the area, at least that's what I use it for.
author: Javier G.

description: I'm a reg. Convenient location and it has a lot of regulars that come. Small bar with a small town vibe, makes this a jewel in the financial district.  Literally right in front of Montgomery Bart so once your done with your round of beers you can hope I'm Bart home without a problem.  Coworkers and I love this spot and make it a part of our weekly routine to come here before the weekend to celebrate the week.
author: JJ S.

description:
The 4 star breakdown: 

Star 1: Reverse happy hour. 12-2, 7-9. Grab lunch, get drunk. 
Star 2: Heavy pours. Get a "shot" of Jameson & you'll see what I mean. 
Star 3: Random lady that gave me a 15 minute back massage. That was nice. 
Star 4: Cute bartender, Natasha. 

Simple man. Simple pleasures.
author: William H L.

description: Great location and strong drinks. Handy happy hour location with a pool table and low key atmosphere.
author: Laurie K.

description:
I'd like to begin this review by stating that I hate the Yelp App today. I just spent 20 mins writing a funny, entertaining review and just because I hit the wrong key on my cell phone, I lost the entire review. Remember to save and save often..

Anyhow.. I recently began working near 4th and Market and decided I needed to explore the night life in the area after work. I get off work about an hour before my BF a couple nights a week and try to kill time by having a cocktail. My first night I chose Sutter Station, a relatively classy dive bar near Embarcadero Station where everyone, and I do mean EVERYONE, was drunk-n-diculous (drunk+rediculous). In fact I do believe the 3 people behind the bar were hands down the most intoxicated patrons in the establishment.

I was VERY warmly greeted and flattered when I arrived. It didn't take but a minute to tell that the bartenders were clearly working the "one drink for you, one drink for me" style that night. (I am refraining from stating which night to protect the employment of these bartenders, because other than being smashed, they were super cool, friendly, and made amazingly delicious and unbelievably strong drinks). I ordered a kamikazi from the bartender who was actually working- apparently two of the people behind the bar weren't working. At least not at that time.  My drink was perfect and probably had nearly 3 shots of vodka in it. After two of them, even with my amazingly high tolerance I was feeling warm and fuzzy, had I had a third I no doubt would've been having as much trouble forming words as the bartenders!!

Sutter Station was surprisingly clean and the decor was such that the 9 to 5 suit and tie crowd would be just as comfortable spending happy hour unwinding from work to avoid the rush hour commute as would tourists, hipsters, or the kind of rough crowd that seems to migrate there on the late night. I recall being surprised at how nice, new, and clean everything looked. Granted it was a quiet night- there were only about a dozen patrons, but I kind of had the feeling it had been recently remoddled or given a face lift at least. I tried to ask the bartenders but the question was never answered- can't imagine why not lol ;-)

Overall I had a lot of fun because of how intertaining the staff was. Don't get me wrong, drunk bartenders are not always a cool thing. It was ok that night because I was in a good mood, had plenty of time, was thrilled by the over pouring of liquor, and was alone so the "show" was welcome. Had it been a busy night, or I'd been with a group, it could of been disastorous. But it was fun that time.
author: Lisa H.

description: Used to be a reg... after embarassing treatment from owner and coked out workers never again!!! If ur looking for a dive bar find another just not worth the drama and rude ownership plus thety add an obnoixous .25 at the end of all drinks and you will never pay the same price for beer
author: Melanie K.

description:
I always thought this place looked cool from the outside so I was dying to check it out. 

It was midnight, I was looking for a nightcap and decided to finally check it out. 

Bartender: We already cleaned the taps so no more draft beers.
Me: No problem: I want a whisky-coke.

The bartender, who's looking pretty salty, walks off, talks to some other customers, serves someone else a beer and comes back.

Barteneder: Bottled beer or shots?
Me: Oh, that's okay. I wanted a whisky-coke.
Bartender: BOTTLED BEER OR SHOTS! WE'RE CLOSING. WHADDAYA WANT?

And that's when I decided, "Fuck this place!" What bar closes at midnight? And so what if you've had a tough night; don't take it out on me.

It's a shame because it does look like a cool bar, lots of seats both at the bar and in booths. That's the only reason I gave it two stars. Maybe I'll go back in a couple years or when they fire that bartender.
author: Car C.

description: Great place to grab a drink.  Reasonable prices, friendly bartenders.  Racer 5 IPA and Lagunitas IPA on draft for $5 and many others.  Only drawback is no kitchen/food.  But as far as drinks, can't ask for much more.  If my review doesn't make complete sense... Sorry I've been drinking.
author: Chris C.

description:
I love this bar. 

Why? Because I had to go to the bathroom, and the guy in the front of the line looked at me and said "Ladies first", and let me go in. 

HOW AWESOME IS THAT.
author: Jaime L.

description:
Oh, the Sutter Gutter...this is my favorite bar in the city, hands down.  As far as it being referred to as a "dive bar", this is by far the cleanest dive bar I've been to. The drinks are strong, and they have two happy hours. By strong, I mean they pour to kill. Thursday nights are the best night to visit, and it's a great place to watch Giants games at. The jukebox has a very random selection of music, & they have 2 pool tables in the back. To top it all off, they have very friendly staff. The owner by the way, is sicilian; not russian, and yes she is feisty, she'll kick you out if she doesn't like you, but treats you great if you're a faithful customer & don't cause any problems. 
This is the bar I take all my friends to when they visit the city, & all of them love it as much as I do! They are cash only; & don't forget to tip your bartender!
author: Alexis H.

description:
Interesting little place. Stopped in last night for their "happy hour". two beers for 9.00 during happy hour still seems a bit pricey - it was bud light, after all. Cool that they do free pizza on fridays tho!

-2 stars for attitude of one bartender who took our order, ignored us, then came back again and asked what we ordered. Um...
author: laura f.

description: i hate to write this. My friends and i LOVE coming to this bar. The bartenders are always friendly and the place is just cozy and welcoming. Other than the night of the superbowl. I am not sure exactly what her issue was but i'm guessing the boss or owner of the place just had it with all of the drunks after superbowl. I showed up with my boyfriend a little after the game was over and instantly got kicked out. I wasnt hammered, stumbling, slurring. Just wanted to go to a bar i enjoy with my man after the game. The blonde lady (who is usually sweet and awesome) was kicking out over half the bar and demanded we leave to. No reason just screaming about how everyone was drunk. It was pitiful. I hate that this happened so much because i really really did enjoy this bar. but that was just stupid.
author: Mandy W.

description: Cash only??? Smells like day old split beer soon as you walk in. No uniforms, grouchy bar tender. Older guy in jeans checks ID's at random after you're already inside. Bar top is well used (trashed).
author: Kamron M.

description: Good for a quick drink in dowtown/Market st.
author: Igor P.

description: Yes, the Sutter Station is 3 stars -- but it is 5 stars for caring about their customers. I have a friend who had a bit too much to drink (don't judge - we have all been there before) and the owner of Sutter Station went above and beyond to make sure my friend got home safely. She was fantastic (and had every reason not to help us....we upset her) and her main concern was focused on my friend and his safe ride home. My loyalty is yours - thank you to the owner of Suttter Station.
author: Joe M.

description:
I love the occasional dive, this one is perfectly placed close to my work - which made my Friday. 

I met Rebecca, a truly friendly awesome bartender at another bar in SF. We started chatting and she mentioned that she worked here and made the best Bloody Mary's in town. Sooo, it was only a matter of time before I HAD to come try them. I was not disappointed.

It was a great Bloody I have to admit, but before I make my choice on the very best bloody mary in SF, I have to do more research.
author: Rebekah T.

description: Smack dab in downtown, Sutter Station is a great divey bar to grab a drink, or play some pool. Just bring cash, because they don't take cards!
author: Natalie S.

description: From the outside, a bar on Market Street I thought would be packed with tourists. Not really the case here at Sutter Station. I stopped by around 6pm, just looking to get one beer before boarding the Muni back home. I asked the bartender what the happy hour special was and he said the specials didn't start until 7pm. But, there were $3 specials for Bud, Bud Light, Pacifico, and I forget the other beers.  $3 Pacifico? SOLD.  Found a spot at the bar, place was not packed at that hour and that was a reprieve. I'd def go back!
author: John M.

description: My favorite classy/divey bar. Strong delicious drinks it they only take cash! try and get there right after work as it gets crowded quickly!
author: Anne N.

description:
If you have been looking for the perfect dive, here it is. Came here before a warriors game on Friday and they hustled the drinks out quick since we were in a hurry, plus I loved the jams people were choosing on the jukebox, 112 in a dive? Hilarious. Plus there are pool tables in the back for those who venture away from the bar itself.

 The 5 stars are for the stupendous bloody mary's and free food at happy hour. Free lumpia and pizza/awesome-spicy bloody mary's? I'm there.
author: Lily G.

description: I think that this place is rather quaint and therefore I do like it. The decor is interesting -- almost as interesting as the type of crowd that they draw which is incredibly diverse. At the end of the day, I can get my glass of wine, try to grab a table, and sit back to relax a bit.
author: Shauna S.

description: Came in with a group to get a few rounds of drinks and play some pool.  Not too crowded and the drinks were good and reasonably priced.  We even got a table to ourselves which is impressive for 7 people.  You can't ask for much more on a Friday night.
author: Kristin F.

description: Ahoy, holiday stroll bar!  I come here once a year and only once a year.  One time, there was popcorn and free pizza.  One time, just cheese crackers.  And one time, there was no food.  I think they have a reverse happy hour deal or else the bartender really liked me and didn't like my friend.  The drinks are as strong as you could hope for.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
This place is a total dive bar in the greatest sense.  When Michael E. and I decided to have a different type of lunch, we headed over to Sutter Station for sandwiches and beer.  I had never even noticed this place until we walked in.  

Similar to Dave's on 3rd Street, the place is dark with a few regulars here and there.  There are some pool tables in the back for people who really want to take a long lunch.  We only had an hour, so we had to get in and out quickly...and we made it with plenty of time.  They have a number of beers on tap - between 6 and 8 - and the bartender was super nice.  When we told her how hungry we were, she offered us some of her lunch (string cheese, yogurt, etc.) which was so nice.  Of course, we refused...since we had just ordered food!

Sutter Station doesn't make its food; they provide a menu from the place next door and call the order in for you.  10 minutes later, a guy arrives with your food.  I ordered the meatball sandwich which was solid but no Snack Depot.  

I mostly like this place for the nice, chatty bartender.  And it's such a great break from the typical FiDi lunch spots...
author: Wendy L.

description:
Sutter Gutter is not for everyone. Those who get it get it and those who dont dont. Its the kind of place thats dimly lit, serves strong drinks from plastic bottles (I just pretend like its all top shelf) and your order might come with a side of lovable sass from the bartender. Its the kind of place you go with friends after a hard days work and time travel until the next morning. Its a dive bar with a face lift...so its safe, clean and you'll see colorful characters of all walks of life...but youre in good boozy unpretentious hands. 

Lets put it this way, I have a permanent scar on my leg from an unfortunate (and funny enough, sober) run in with a pool table there....and Im proud of my Sutter Scar!
author: Seana L.

description:
"I want my two dollars!!!"

I've been to this bar several times. I have a pretty standard bar order, vodka soda with soda on the side. (Gotta stay hydrated). Bartenders everywhere accommodate this request for "soda on the side" without charging me (really it's just like water, the amount of C02 used in a glass of soda probably costs the bar less than a cent). 

Now there are some places where you can expect to get charged for extra soda, like pricey hotel bars or nightclubs. But even in places without a soda gun, where they pour from bottles of club soda, I don't have to pay extra. 

The other day, however, I placed my usual order and was charged an extra two bucks for soda. I know it's a minor issue, and this is a rant, but even dive bars should treat patrons  with respect. 

I asked the bartender if he just charged me for soda and he said, "yes, it's extra. It's another drink." (seriously?) When I let him know that EVERY time I've been in there I haven't been charged, he looked at me oddly and said dismissively "that's not the way we do things here." (He really seemed to have his finger on the Sutter Station pulse).
 
Interesting and idiotic. Does he realize that I was going to give him the two bucks as a tip? And if he gave me the $2 back I'd actually tip him $3? Would he rather put $2 in the till for the bar owners rather than his own pocket? Piss off a regular customer? I just don't like to hang around in the presence of stupid bartenders, and it seems this place is rife with 'em. Pissing people off seems to be "the way they do things" at this place. 

There are a lot of better options for a quick after work drink (a few on second street and one on first street between market and mission). I'm sure I'll be back as it's rarely as crowded as the other places (wonder why?) and all I want is a drink while I wait for my wife to get off work. I'll just make sure I don't sit down in front of that jerk from the other day. 

I honestly can't recommend this place as being a good bar. It's only marginally tolerable without the bad treatment. If I walk back in there, they'll probably spit in my drink for this, but the vodka they serve should easily kill any germs they carry.
author: Jason G.

description:
Yes this place is dirty, dark, and dingy and has a bunch of cool degenerates as patrons, but what do you expect at a dive bar.

It is a dive bar people and a damn good one. Every time I have been, it has been nothing but good ol' drunken times with friends.

This place  is great for happy hour with cheap prices and decent selection of alcohol and beer. Come here if a dive bar is what you are looking for in the night!
author: Richard K.

description: Aokay, good venue, choices, reasonably priced and a fund place...good waitstaff, and decently priced, especially during happy hour...easy to find and able to drop in, order a drink and stay or go on by choice....would try again!
author: R J.

description: Magnificent place to chill after a day at your Financial District startup, or to drown your sorrows as said startup plows inevitably toward shut-down. They make a mean martini, several in a row if you ask nicely. Just don't expect your significant other to understand why you came home plastered and fell asleep with your head on the dining room table after he/she spent the evening making a special salmon dinner - you'll know.
author: Scott D.

description:
It IS dirty, noisy, and lacking staff.  Dirty, smells like smoke from the people standing outside the doorways (front and back), and I think they only take cash and no Debit Card / Credit Cards.  Hello, this is the future. 

I guess the place could be fun with a good crowd, however, WHO wants to drink right downstairs or near your office and if your bosses can see you?  Arghhh!
author: Allen S.

description: Hey, it's a close dive bar that gets the job done.  No frills, but sometimes no frills is what you're in the mood for -- I'd rather do that than dressed to the nines any day.  Also, they have Lagunitas on tap -- can't go wrong with that.
author: Mel G.

description:
When I first started working downtown, I asked a colleague "Why don't we ever go to Sutter Station for happy hour? It's so close!" I don't think I was even granted a response. And now I know why. Thank you, Twelve Drinking Days of Christmas! As I walked up to the door and had my ID checked by "Security" (hip hop music blasting from within), it didn't take long before the lightbulb went off. Here were my clues that this place was a shithole:

- On my way back to the pool tables, I was winked and hollered at by 3 old men.
- At the bar, I couldn't order a drink because the bartender was busy kissing a patron.
- Everyone was utterly wasted by 6pm. 
- A drunky-faced man came up to us and screamed "I'm an alcoholic!" then proceeded to drop his glass on the floor.
- Free fried chicken and pizza for all?

Needless to say, I was uncomfortable and got out of there as soon as my 1 pt was earned for TDDOC.
author: Susan L.

description:
A dive bar in the Financial District, how come I just found out about this place?

Full bar, quirky staff, interesting regulars, free popcorn; what more could you want?

One thing though; do not take the popcorn out of the popper, ask the staff to help you.
author: Manny F.

description: Dive.  Not as awful as it used to be 5-10 years ago, but pretty awful still.  Never mind yappies gathering to watch soccer at the lunch hour.  They are treated no better than junkies, cheap whores and hobos - it's normal clientele.  The service is rude and uncaring.  Like, they really do not care about their customers.  For example, they would rather yell at people with beers not to put their drinks on the pool table than to cover the the pool table for the time of the game!!  Result?  I'd just watch soccer and not buy anything.  Oh, and there is no food served.  And, they card even 70-year old man the other day.  The dumbest dive I've ever seen!  I mean, if I were the manager, I would come to the watchers and offer to bring them something.  Right?  This place could have made a killing!!  But - no.  Instead, they hustle you if you DO buy something.  Wtf?!?!
author: LANA R.

description:
Not a bad bar, just a strange location.  Often a good crowd with friendly bartenders. 

Just a lot of vagrants outside who might ask you for your money...

And although the place offers wifi, it would kind of be weird to be surfing on your computer here...
author: Mark M.

description:
We went for a few beers since it's just down the block from where my coworkers and I do business.

There was this short fat girl that works that was very rude, not just to us, but to other patrons as well. No only was the service bad, the place too cramped, but above all else the bartender was just rude and obnoxious.

I definitely do not recommend this mediocre and overpriced place at all!!!!
author: Mauricio V.

description:
I go here when I'm in the mood for bottles of Budweiser ($3) and, now that I've discovered Sutter Station, is more often than I ever realized.  If you go in expecting a dive bar, then you will be satisfied.  The crowd is diverse (which is a nice change from the usual Financial District bars), the juke box doesn't have any music on it from after 2001, the bartenders get the job done, and they only take cash.  Except they have free Wi-fi!  That always weirds me out (but is nice). 

I'm from small town Wisconsin so this is exactly what I need sometimes to get away from the hype.  My only complaint is that their happy hour is opposite, 3-5pm and 7-9pm I think, but, like I said, $3 Bud hits the spot more often than not.
author: Luthien N.

description:
Great spot for a quick drink but the pool tables and jukebox help you stay a few hours.

Drinks are cheap and poured heavy.

Cash only but there's an ATM in the back.

No food but you can bring in your own.

Solid place overall.
author: Tyler W.

description:
Call Sutter Station whatever you want, but I'm calling it a dive bar in light of my most recent experience:

My buddies and I are playing a round of pool when a fight breaks out at the door. I can't really make much sense of what's going on, the owner (a tiny but fiery Russian woman) comes running out to yell at the brawlers, then the bouncer intervenes, gets punched in the teeth, and the assailant bolts down the road. The bouncer then spent the next 30 minutes trying to find his two front teeth while the owner was flipping out, talking about how she's gonna find that s.o.b. and "take care of him."

Quality dive bar at its finest.
author: Anthony C.

description: Need a cheap dive bar that is close to work and all public transportation? Then search no more Sutter Station is your place. It can get pretty darn crowded and always is kinda busy. Dark, well used (worn down), filled with a random mix of people from professional to shady. Yet seriously cheap drinks and and well located.
author: Natasha M.

description:
Oh man--this place makes me want to start a new list: Bars in Which to Drunkenly Fantasize, after Maybe the Third or Fourth Happy Hour (ie, Empty Stomach) Drink, Having Unprotected, Bathroom Stall Sex with Some 55-year-old Patron/Employee/Fishnet-stockinged Cigarette Seller. (But really probably she ends up being a patron). Point being, what a wonderful place. Because realize: 

a) This is an establishment at Ground Zero of the Financial District, and yet it is,
b) about as divey as they come, viz., 
c) it opens at--god I don't even know when it opens--at 9 in the morning? 7? 7, for god's sake?
d) Put in other, plainly geographic terms, it's a Turk & Taylor bar a (good, long, hard) stone's throw from the Federal Reserve, a place where plenty of people who gently move away from Certain People when they encounter them on MUNI pull up actual stools next to Certain People and order whiskeys, neat.
e) I.e., you just don't get this kind of demographic eddy anywhere else in the city. 

And so I give it 4 stars, even though it can get loud, which, man I don't like that in a bar, and even though it can get really crowded, and even though, yeah, ok, I'll admit it, 85% of the time I walk by there on a Thursday or Friday night at like 6 pm I think some iteration or other of the thought, Who would *ever* go there?? Which totally makes no sense, I'll freely admit, but sometimes you just have to reward a place for being like no other, and, yes, for holding down the Fort of Inadvisable Things, because you never know when you're going to want to go back, and when that time comes when you want to go back, you'll actually need to.
author: T U.

description:
It's common knowledge by now, but I like divey joints like this and no one knows this better than Esco.  She'd found this place while hurriedly seeking out a restroom during Pride weekend, and knew from the start that she'd HAVE TO bring me back one day...

We checked it out after work while waiting to meet with Keeks for dinner.  From the outside, the place looks sketch and stepping through the awning shadowed doorway, the initial "Danger, Will Robinson, Danger!" sensation isn't immediately abated; the long and narrow alley of a room stays dark till your eyes adjust to the dim lights.  Until then, its hard to separate the unsavory types from the 9-to-5 crowd (sure enough, its mostly an afterwork crowd winding down...)

*Scene: At the jukebox, a really inebriated couple (clearly co-workers) grind up against each other to Earth Wind and Fire's "September".

We walked to the length of the bar, taking inventory of what taps and bottles they offered (E and I take our casual drinking too seriously!), noticing some uncommon brews.

*Scene: A pungent patron stumbles off his barstool and wobbles towards the door. The bartender sprays the area with Febreeze and Lysol. Liberally.

Beyond the bar, there's another room with a few pool tables and... [dramatic pause]... Oh, spider-senses tingling!  But this time, I trust it; something about [my Islander] people back there vibes of 'Yay-ee-YAY", area code hollarin', hooliganism. Keep clear.

*Scene: Conversations hush and eyes dart back and forth, assessing angles, on both the game on the pool table and people in the room. Friendly competition, this ain't.
